body:
I forgot to write this in the docs, but dropbox is case insensitive which explains some of the above.

I tried to replicate this but I couldn't yet...

Is it just the the tools directory which appears duplicated?  Where did it come from?  Did you upload it?

Can you make a reproducer for me so I can see the problem on my dropbox account?

Thanks

Nick

I would use rClone wizard (rclone config) to create a local file system
config as well instead of using:

~/data

Maybe call it downloadto: . This should resolve the issue.

All the best,

Zeshan

On Tue, May 5, 2015 at 4:12 AM, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I forgot to write this in the docs, but dropbox is case insensitive which
> explains some of the above.
> 
> I tried to replicate this but I couldn't yet...
> 
> Is it just the the tools directory which appears duplicated? Where did it
> come from? Did you upload it?
> 
> Can you make a reproducer for me so I can see the problem on my dropbox
> account?
> 
> Thanks
> 
> Nick
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/53#issuecomment-98989366.
Thanks, it'll try to reproduce it on standalone account. I'll also try rclone config for local file system (just in case).

I've found https://www.dropboxforum.com/hc/communities/public/questions/201665409-Wrong-character-case-of-folder-name-when-calling-listFolder-using-Sync-API?locale=en-us

Looks like only last path component is case-reliable:

> Dropbox and the API itself are case insensitive, so in some cases you will see this behavior. (We realize this is non-ideal of course and are looking into ways to improve.) That said, the best solution here is to do a case-insensitive search in your code too.
>  Also, the last path component will always be the expected case though, so alternatively you can build up the paths manually on your side just using those.

I've checked (via printf), Dropbox API returns paths in different cases in Entry.Path.
Also stripRoot works incorrectly in that case.

yikes. The linux OS is case sensitive all the way..as you already know :(

Have you tried rClone on windows os? Is it same behavior on windows OS?

Regards,
Zeshan

On Tue, May 5, 2015 at 10:44 AM, Leonid Shalupov notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I've checked (via printf), Dropbox API returns paths in different cases in
> Entry.Path.
> Also stripRoot works incorrectly in that case.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/53#issuecomment-99100726.

@shalupov thanks for the investigation - that link is useful.

I'll have a think on how to make rclone ignore the case in paths.

The easiest way would be just to lower case everything, but that isn't ideal as people really like the case in their file names to be correct!

The other way will involve building an internal map of paths in lower case.  This should be possible since the last component is always case-reliable.
I've made a note about this in the rclone docs which will appear shortly at http://rclone.org/drive/

rename.to: dropbox: case insensitivity causes duplicated files

issue.title: Record names coming from Dropbox API, fixes #53

I fixed #53 
I'll be happy to fix any issues with this pull request

issue.title: Dropbox: Problem syncing some folders - probably due to case insensitivity.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Hi Nick,

I'm having a problem with syncing some (but not all) folders. I'm sure it's down to the case (in)sensitivity of Dropbox but I can't understand why it's only happening with some folders. This is the command I'm running:

rclone sync -v --size-only dropbox:Documents/ local:/home/darren/test/

Some files (particularly in the Finance folder) are causing the following error and not syncing:

2015/06/11 11:07:11 /documents/finance/2010/Vacuum Belts.pdf: Failed to open: file does not exist

In Dropbox, the path is actually /Documents/Finance/ - note the upper case D and F - but like I said, I don't know why it seems to only be affecting the Finance folder. Other sub-folders of Documents (also containing an upper-case first letter) are syncing OK.
